title: John Simpson (rugby union)
text:
John Simpson (2 September 1872 – 11 January 1921) was a <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. He later became an international referee and was the 31st <a href="President%20of%20the%20Scottish%20Rugby%20Union">President</a> of the <a href="Scottish%20Rugby%20Union">Scottish Rugby Union</a>.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
Simpson played with <a href="Royal%20HSFP">Royal HSFP</a>.
Provincial career.
Simpson played for <a href="Edinburgh%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Edinburgh District</a> against <a href="Glasgow%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Glasgow District</a> in the 1894 inter-city match.
International career.
Simpson was capped eleven times for <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> between 1893 and 1899. He was part of the Scotland side that won the Triple Crown in 1894-95 season.
Referee career.
He refereed one international match in the <a href="1906%20Home%20Nations%20Championship">1906 Home Nations Championship</a>; the Ireland v Wales match.
Administrative career.
He became the 31st President of the Scottish Rugby Union. He served one year from <a href="List%20of%20Scottish%20Rugby%20Union%20Presidents">1904 to 1905</a>.
Medical career.
Simpson became a doctor. He was a Fellow of the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Physicians%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh</a> and a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh.
Death.
He died on 11 January 1921, leaving a widow Margaret Lockhart Mitchell. His estate was valued at £5204, 19 shillings and 3d. He is buried in Dean Cemetery in Edinburgh.
